fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
In JIRA 3.9, new automation is introduced where it can Auto-Approve a request when a certain condition is met. While the automation works properly, it appears that it does not provide a "Tick" icon for any Approver that is added in that transition.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create/Edit a Workflow where there is approval needed in status after a request is created.
# Create an Automation where it will Auto-Approve in the same status with certain conditions to be met.
# Create a Request with an Approver and met the necessary conditions to trigger the automation.

h3. Expected Results
The issue will be moved to the next Status without the Approver need to Approve/Decline it with the users in "Past Approvals" is ticked.

h3. Actual Results
The issue will be moved to the next Status with the "Past Approvals" users is not ticked.

h3. Note:
In case that this is expected behavior, such information is not given in the documentation below where it mentions there should be a tick:
- [Setting up Approvals|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskserver/setting-up-approvals-939926369.html]

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: No "Tick" icon for Auto-Approved step

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

There's warnings being triggered on the latest JSD version due to the `RequestCacheImpl` being used outside of a request thread by the `SdSerialisedOffThreadProcessor`. This will not work in the future, so we need to fix it.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install JSD v4.9.1

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-jira.log file:
{noformat}
SdSerialisedOffThreadProcessor:thread-4 WARN [c.a.j.cache.request.RequestCacheImpl] Incorrect usage of JIRA API. You can only create/use: RequestCacheImpl inside a context (request or Jira-Thread-Local). Check: JiraThreadLocalUtil for details.
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Setting the log level of the {{com.atlassian.jira.cache.request.RequestCacheImpl}} package to ERROR per the documentation [Logging and profiling|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver/logging-and-profiling-938847671.html]

(i) This configuration will filter out relevant warnings as well.

h4. Temporary way to set the package to ERROR (this setting will go away after a Jira restart)

- In Jira, go to *⚙ > System > Logging and profiling page*
- Scroll down to *Default Loggers > Configure logging level for another package*, and add {{com.atlassian.jira.cache.request.RequestCacheImpl}} package with the ERROR level


h4. Permanent way to set the package to ERROR (this setting will remain after a Jira restart)

- Edit the file {{<JIRA_INSTALLATION>/atlassian-jira/WEB-INF/classes/log4j.properties}}
- Add the 2 following lines at the end of the file and save it:
{code}
log4j.logger.com.atlassian.jira.cache.request.RequestCacheImpl = ERROR, filelog
log4j.additivity.com.atlassian.jira.cache.request.RequestCacheImpl = false
{code}
- Restart the Jira application
fields.summary: RequestCache being used in an invalid context

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When creating a Request in the Customer Portal, it is possible to set the Organization to share the Request. Once the request is created, the 'Organization added' notification is not sent out. This prevents the Organization members from being notified of the Request shared and they wouldn't be able to opt-in for further notifications (unless followed via Customer Portal)

Checking the Customer Notification Audit Log, we can see that the rule is not executed. The rule would be executed if the Organization field is edited in existing Requests.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In a Service Desk Project, create an Organization and add a Customer user in it
 # Create a new Request in the Customer Portal and share it to the Organization during creation
 # After the Request is created, the 'Organization added' notification would not be sent out
 # Checking the 'Organization added' Audit Log, it was not executed for the created Request despite being shared to the Organization

h3. Expected Results

The 'Organization added' notification would be sent out to the Organization members
h3. Actual Results

The 'Organization added' notification is not sent out to the Organization members
h3. Workaround

Edit the 'Organization' members to revoke and share back the Request
fields.summary: 'Organization added' notification is not sent out when Request is shared to Organization during creation

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

With a large number of users (in our case, north of 1 million), typing to search for users in the "Alert user" field of a "THEN" automation workflow action causes a spike in CPU utilization, followed by constant garbage collection at a level that renders that node in the cluster unable to respond to any other requests until the service is manually restarted.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Navigate to the "Project settings" area of a Service Desk project
 # Click "Automation" in the sidebar
 # Either edit an existing rule or create a new one
 # If necessary (if creating a new rule), add an applicable "WHEN" action (such that adding a "THEN" action is possible)
 # Add a "THEN" action; select the "Alert user" action
 # In the resulting text field, type some characters to select a user
 # Wait for list of users to return; see that the response takes a long time (30+ sec) and may not ever return (receiving error message: "The call to the Jira server did not complete within the timeout period. We are unsure of the result of this operation.")

h3. Expected Results

Searching for a user returns results in a reasonable amount of time for the specificity of the query and the service should remain available.
h3. Actual Results
 # Each character typed into the field results in a request like the following: {{/rest/servicedesk/automation/servicedeskmodules/1/then/alertuser/search?usernameOrEmail=b&projectKey=ABC&_=1591399088734}}
 # Every time the text field gains/loses focus, the same request is sent again
 # If the user interprets the long response time as an indication that the user they're searching for doesn't exist, they may choose to clear the field with their backspace key; each press to erase a character also sends a request
 # While a search for one or two characters, or even a copy/pasted username (a single request) may return successfully (though after a long delay; 30+ sec), a user who types a long username or email address, waits, sees no response, then backspaces their way back through the query can easily generate 20-30 requests in just a few seconds; this activity is enough to cause:
 ** High CPU
 ** High JVM memory usage
 ** Continuous garbage collection
 ** Service instability and potential unavailability (if the user attempting these searches bounces to other nodes in the cluster (as a result of nodes becoming unhealthy) and attempts their search again)

h3. Workaround

At the load balancer or other proxy in front of Jira, block requests on the path {{/rest/servicedesk/automation/servicedeskmodules/1/then/alertuser/search}} to prevent these search requests from reaching Jira. Obviously this has the side-effect of disabling the functionality entirely, but it does prevent users from triggering this issue.
fields.summary: Typing query into JSD "Alert user" automation "THEN" action causes constant GC and service instability

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Today, the way customer permissions work, there is no way to limit a customer existing in projects which we may not want them too..  The end impact of this is that once a customer is created in Jira, they are made available as reporters and customers  to all JSD projects.. Which is not good behaviour as in multi-helpdesk environments, it could lead to accidents.

e.g. we now need to add a public facing project. Let's call it project A. Project A will NOT use the portal, but will only accept emails from outside users. We have no way to pre-create these accounts as they will be from unknown users. This works perfectly. User sends email, gets email, all good..

The issue we have is that when this customer/reporter is created, they are added to the Customers list of that project (perfect); however, we have Projects B through F which are internal JSD projects and are known users which sync from an LDAP source and are customers. The problem we have is that the Customers that are created in Project A become available as customers/reporters in Projects B-F. This could lead to someone accidentally using the wrong user if they modify the reporter...

Our desire would be to have the users/Customers from Project A created in project and NOT in projects B-F - or have them unavailble to use as a reporter.. How can we do that?
fields.summary: JSD - Limit Customers/Reporters to specific projects

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

In some cases, if an incoming mail used to reply to an existing ticket contains attachments which names match the names of attachments that are already in the ticket, the mail will fail to be processed.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

The exact steps to reproduce are not clear yet as we haven't been able to reproduce it in our environment. However, from what we observed, the issue seems to happen:
 - when the existing ticket was created with attachment before an upgrade to JSD 4.8.0 (Jira 8.8.0)
 - when the reply to this ticket (containing attachments of same name) was sent after the upgrade to JSD 4.8.0 (Jira 8.8.0)

h3. Expected Results

The email should be processed a new comment should be added to the ticket, along with the attachments.
h3. Actual Results

The email fails to be processed, and the following error will be thrown in the Jira logs:
{code:java}
2020-06-05 11:33:06,311+0300 Caesium-1-3 ERROR XXX [c.a.p.i.util.runner.AuthenticationContextUtilImpl] Unexpected error while running action as user 'XXX'
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Duplicate key com.atlassian.jira.issue.attachment.Attachment@ffffff2a
at java.util.stream.Collectors.lambda$throwingMerger$0(Collectors.java:133)
at java.util.HashMap.merge(HashMap.java:1254)
at java.util.stream.Collectors.lambda$toMap$58(Collectors.java:1320)
at java.util.stream.ReduceOps$3ReducingSink.accept(ReduceOps.java:169)
at java.util.ArrayList$ArrayListSpliterator.forEachRemaining(ArrayList.java:1382)
at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.copyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:481)
at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.wrapAndCopyInto(AbstractPipeline.java:471)
at java.util.stream.ReduceOps$ReduceOp.evaluateSequential(ReduceOps.java:708)
at java.util.stream.AbstractPipeline.evaluate(AbstractPipeline.java:234)
at java.util.stream.ReferencePipeline.collect(ReferencePipeline.java:499)
at com.atlassian.servicedesk.internal.comment.InternalServiceDeskCommentServiceImpl.getOriginalAttachments(InternalServiceDeskCommentServiceImpl.java:500)
{code}
or:
{code:java}
2020-04-02 23:36:53,401+0200 Caesium-1-2 ERROR thomas.soupart@exxoss.com     [c.a.p.i.util.runner.AuthenticationContextUtilImpl] Unexpected error while running action as user 'user'
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Duplicate key image001.png (attempted merging values com.atlassian.jira.issue.attachment.Attachment@ffffff2a and com.atlassian.jira.issue.attachment.Attachment@fffff955)
	at java.base/java.util.stream.Collectors.duplicateKeyException(Collectors.java:133)
{code}
h3. Workaround
h4. Workaround 1

Remove all the images imageXXX.png directly from the ticket created before the Service Desk upgrade to 4.8.0. By doing this, new emails sent to these tickets that contain the same attachments imageXXX.png should be added successfully.
h4. Workaround 2

When replying to an email to add a comment to an existing ticket, make sure that this email does not contain signature image (remove any image with file names such as imageXXX.png.
fields.summary: Some incoming mails containing attachment failed to be processed

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a user search for customers and organizations, the browser returns error 500. This behavior occurs only under the following circumstances (highlighted below)
h3. Environment (Specific to)
 * Jira Service Desk connected to Microsoft SQL Server
 * There are more than 2100 organizations in the Jira Service Desk project
 * Customer permissions for 'Who can raise requests?' is set to _Customers who are added to the project_

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Setup a Jira Service Desk instance connected to Microsoft SQL Server
 # Configure the Jira Service Desk project with a large number of organization. In this example, we have 8000 organizations
 (i) You may use {{[POST /rest/servicedeskapi/organization|https://docs.atlassian.com/jira-servicedesk/REST/4.9.0/#servicedeskapi/organization-createOrganization]}} REST API to create organization and then {{[POST /rest/servicedeskapi/servicedesk/\{serviceDeskId}/organization|https://docs.atlassian.com/jira-servicedesk/REST/4.9.0/#servicedeskapi/servicedesk/\{serviceDeskId}/organization-addOrganization]}} to add the organization to the project
 # Run a full re-index to ensure indexes are in sync
 # Navigate to the Jira Service Desk project 'Customer' page
 # Search for customers and organizations with any string

h3. Expected Results

Search results returned correctly.
h3. Actual Results

The search failed with a pop-up error.

!mssql-search.png|thumbnail!

The below exception is thrown in the _atlassian-jira-http-dump.log_ file:
{code:java}
127.0.0.1 i000x000000x0 admin [26/May/2020:16:32:59 +0200] "GET http://localhost:8870/jira870/rest/servicedesk/1/pages/people/customers/pagination/JSD/search HTTP/1.1" - - - "http://localhost:8870/jira870/projects/JSD/customers" 

127.0.0.1 o000x000000x0 admin [26/May/2020:16:32:59 +0200] "GET http://localhost:8870/jira870/rest/servicedesk/1/pages/people/customers/pagination/JSD/search HTTP/1.1" 500 26716 0,0790 "http://localhost:8870/jira870/projects/JSD/customers" 
        ___ Request _____________________________________________________
        
        ...

        ___ Response ____________________________________________________
        Response HTTP Headers : 
            X-AUSERNAME=admin
            Content-Type=application/json
            Cache-Control=no-cache, no-store, no-transform
        Response Data (first 24576 of 26716 bytes) : 
    
    "Caught SQLServerException for select \"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION_MEMBER\".\"USER_KEY\" from \"jiraschema\".\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION_MEMBER\" \"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION_MEMBER\" inner join \"jiraschema\".\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\" \"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\" on \"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" \u003d \"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION_MEMBER\".\"ORGANIZATION_ID\" where \"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" in (?, ..., ?) or (\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" in (?, ..., ?)) or (\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" in (?, ..., ?)) or (\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" in (?, ..., ?)) or (\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" in (?, ..., ?)) or (\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" in (?, ..., ?)) or (\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" in (?, ..., ?)) or (\"AO_54307E_ORGANIZATION\".\"ID\" in (?, ..., ?
{code}
h3. Workaround
*Option 1*
Enable the {{sd.use.search.by.permissions.disabled}} dark feature, by following the steps below:
- Navigate to following address: http(s)://<jira_base_url>/secure/SiteDarkFeatures!default.jspa
- Add the following flag and Enable:
{code}
sd.use.search.by.permissions.disabled
{code}

*Option 2*
Switch to the following options for the 'Who can raise requests?' customer permissions
- Customers who have an account on this Jira site
- Anyone can email the service desk or raise a request in the portal
fields.summary: Search for customers and organizations in SQL Server returns error 500

fields.description:
*Problem:*
At the Service Desk frontend Portal, the label of the most part of the fields (system and custom fields) are not accessible with a screen reader.

*The environment used for the test:*
 Mac Osx default screen reader
 Firefox 76.0.1

*Steps to Reproduce:*
 * Create a default IT Service Desk Project area;
 * Create some Custom fields, for instance:
 ** "Browsers" - Select List (multiple choices)
 ** "Issue Category" - Selection list (single) - add 
 ** "Issue Description" - Text Field (multi-line)
 ** "Jira Projet URL" - URL field
 ** "Jira Project key" - Text Field (single line)
 * Add these fields on the Portal:
 ** Project settings > Request Types
 ** Edit Fields for the "Report a system problem" and add the new custom fields;
 * Open a Firefox browser and reach the portal;
 * Select <Report a system Problem>;
 * Hit <tab> to reach each field;

*Expected behavior:*
 * Screen Reader identifies each field.

*Observed behavior:*
 * Most of the fields were not identified:
  
||Action||Type||Reader Action||Observed Problem||
|cursor at <Summarize the problem> field|Summary
 system field|Summarize the Problem; Clickable, text; You are currently on a text field|(/)|
|cursor at <Description (optional)> field|Description
 system field
 Wiki Style Renderer|Description, optional; you are currently on a text field|(/)|
|cursor at <Select a system (optional)> field|Components
 system field |Clickable, text list, 2 items; you are currently on a text field|a) Label was not read 
 b) There are 7 options, not 2|
|cursor at <How urgent is this> field|priority
 system field|Clickable, text, main; you are currently on a text field|a) Label was not read
 b) No mention that there are 3 options to select|
|cursor at <What's the impact> field|impact
 system field|Clickable, text; you are currently on a text field|a) Label was not read
 b) There are 3 options|
|cursor at <Browser(s) (optional)> field|custom field 
 Select List (multiple choices)|Clickable, text list, 2 items; you are currently on a text field|a) Label was not read
 b) There are 3 options|
|Cursor at <Issue Category (optional)> field|custom field 
 Selection list (single)|Clickable, text, main; you are currently on a text field|a) Label was not read
 b) No mention that there are 3 options to select|
|Cursor at <Issue description (optional)> field|custom field
 Text Field (multi-line)|Issue description, optional; Clickable, text; you are currently on a text field|(/)|
|Cursor at <Jira project URL (optional)> field|custom field
 URL field|Jira project URL, optional, Clickable, text; you are currently on a text field|(/)|
|Cursor at <Jira project key (optional)> field|custom field
 Text Field (single line)|Jira project key, optional, Clickable, text; you are currently on a text field|(/)|

*Business impact*

 !Screenshot 2020-06-04 at 13.45.13.png|thumbnail!

requests should also filter status and request type
h3. Actual Results
filter on status and request type doesn't work in combination with shared with my organizations.
h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, Jira Service Desk only allows Request Type list to be re-ordered in Customer Portal view. Admins are not able to reorder values in "Customer Request Type" custom field.


h3. Suggested Solution

Allow admins to reorder the options in "Customer Request Type" custom field similar to other custom field type such as "Select List (single choice): custom field type.


h3. Workaround 

None
fields.summary: Allow admins to reorder Customer Request Type in regular issue view

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Customers in organizations can share issues with undesired organizations

h3. Steps to Reproduce
Currently, when a user in multiple organizations, they can share an issue to an organization that users on the ticket are not members of. This could cause sharing with users or organizations that should not have access to a ticket of that type. We would like an option to restrict sharing based on the organizations the users on the ticket are not a member of.

Example:
-Purple: Org 1, Org 2
-Blue: Org 1
-Red: Org 2

Blue is creating a ticket and wants to share with Purple for an issue with Org 1 issue. Purple can access as they are a member of Org 1 and Org 2. Purple can then share the ticket with Red for the same reason. Red should not have access to the ticket based on their role within the company/team.

h3. Expected Results
The user in Purple organization should not be able to share with Red

h3. Actual Results
Customer in purple can share the issue with Red

h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Customers in organizations can share issues with undesired organizations

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When the resolution email is sent out after resolving a ticket, it seems to be very specific on where you need to click to be redirected to the satisfaction page when using Outlook.

It appears that the right half side of the star is not clickable and only the left-hand side works properly.

+Notes+:
 * This is exactly the same issue reported for Cloud in JSDCLOUD-6017.
 * Some suggestions were created to address this behavior (e.g JSDSERVER-5539) but this looks more like a bug in the HTML/CSS code.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # In a Service Desk Project, create an issue as a customer.  
 # Make sure the Satisfaction Setting in the Jira Service Desk is configured and turned on. 
 # Resolve that issue as an agent, this will generate the customer satisfaction survey
 # As a customer, open the Outlook 2016 client and access the notification with the satisfaction survey
 # Click on any one of the 5 stars to the "right side" of the star, you will notice it does not trigger a link generation and open the web page with the survey. 
 # Click on any one of the 5 stars to the "left side" of the star, you will notice it does trigger a link generation and open the web page with the survey.

h3. Expected Results

The customer should be able to click on any part of the "star" to generate the survey link in the browser. 
h3. Actual Results

The customer is able to click on the left side of the "star" to generate the survey link in the browser, however, the right side of the star is not responsive.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: Stars in Satisfaction Survey Not Responding Properly in Outlook

For now, the agent's closing comments email and resolution email are designed separately and there is no way to include them together in the same email body. This suggestion is to include the agent's closing comments in the resolution email body rather than having them as two separate emails or bulked together.
h3. Why this suggestion:

As per the customer, "it's a bit annoying you get one nicely formatted resolution email and then a chunk of text for the comment underneath that!"
fields.summary: Include the agent's closing comments in the resolution email body

fields.description:
Users want to pull reports that include fields that are not present/available on an issue. 

For example, Users want to pull custom reports including these fields in Jira Service Desk - Groups of Request types, Customer Request Type, Project and Request URL (From Customer Portal). 

Here we see some fields that are available as Issue fields (Project and Customer Request Type) and other fields that are not present in issues (Groups of Request types and Request URL).  As the latter fields are not available as issue fields, we cannot pull the report through JQL.

It would be useful if important non-issue fields are also included to form JQL query. It would help users to generate reports.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

In JIRA 4.8 onwards, we are allowed to managing multiple issues at once with bulk actions from the queue view level. It is called Agent Queues Experience (Bulk Editing). It Is Showing Delete Button Even When Agent Doesn't Have A Delete Permission
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Step 1 Setup JIRA Service Desk 4.8
 # Step 2 Access to the queue and select multiple tickets, you will see Delete Button show up
 !image-2020-05-27-22-28-04-525.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results

If the agent/admin doesn't have delete issue permission, the button shouldn't be showing up.
h3. Actual Results

Delete button showing even though agent/admin doesn't have delete issue permission
h3. Workaround

There is no workaround to fix the button yet, but you can disable it by access to JIRA's Dark Feature in [<JIRA_BASE_URL>/secure/SiteDarkFeatures!default.jspa|http://localhost:8080/secure/SiteDarkFeatures!default.jspa], and add *sd.queue.bulk.actions.disabled* to disable the feature.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The changes added for https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-70137 in Jira changed the way we check for visible comments for our users, and since JSD has a new type of user ("Customer") those changes affected us since "Customer" type users do not have BROWSE_PROJECTS permission (and should not have). 

This bug causes all recalculations of SLAs with the "Comment: for customers" condition to be wrongly recalculated and corrupted, explaining what we are seeing in this ticket.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new project in an empty JSD
 # Create a new SLA configuration like this: Start: Issue created, Pause: Status: Waiting for Customer, Stop: Comment: for customer
 # Create a new customer user using self sign-up
 # Use that customer to open a ticket through the customer portal
 # As an agent, go to the ticket and add a public comment. The SLA will be correctly stopped and complete.
 # Now, to break the SLA: delete the SLA values for the issue using the following SQL:
{noformat}
delete
from customfieldvalue
where issue in (
    select id as issue_id
    from jiraissue
    where project = (
        select id as project_id
        from project
        where pkey = '{PROJECT_KEY}' -- project key
    )
      and issuenum = {ISSUE_NUMBER} -- issue number
)
  and customfield in (
    select id as sla_custom_field_id
    from customfield
    where customfieldtypekey = 'com.atlassian.servicedesk:sd-sla-field' --sla field type key
);
{noformat}
 # Now execute a call like below to Jira's REST to clear the cache (replace the auth strategy with whatever makes sense):
{noformat}
curl --location --request DELETE 'http://localhost:2990/jira/rest/internal/1.0/cache/app' \
     --header 'Authorization: Basic {BASE64_AUTH_STRING}' {noformat}
 # Call the reconstruct API on the issue (we might need to enable the sd.sla.fix.timeline feature flag here (again, replace the auth strategy with whatever makes sense):
{noformat}
curl --location --request POST 'http://localhost:2990/jira/rest/servicedesk/1/servicedesk/sla/admin/task/destructive/reconstruct' \
     --header 'Authorization: Basic {BASE64_AUTH_STRING}' \
     --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
     --data-raw '["{ISSUE_KEY}"]'{noformat}

h3. Expected Results

The SLA should be in a correct state after calling the full reconstruction API.
h3. Actual Results

SLA is now in a broken state. For example, SLAs that should have been paused / stopped are still running

h3. Workaround

h5. Workaround for a specific issue in 3.16.x
# Add Browser projects permission to the Reporter role (accessing a URL like this: http://localhost:2990/jira/secure/admin/EditPermissions!default.jspa?schemeId=10000)
# Find an issue in a broken state (aka: with a Comment: for customer stop condition that should’ve been triggered but isn’t)
# Run the reconstruction for the affected issue via REST API, like so (remember to change the authorisation strategy to something that makes sense for the instance):
{noformat}
curl --location --request POST 'http://localhost:2990/jira/rest/servicedesk/1/servicedesk/sla/admin/task/destructive/reconstruct' \
     --header 'Authorization: Basic {BASE64_AUTH_STRING}' \
     --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
     --data-raw '["{ISSUE_KEY}"]'{noformat}
# SLA is now fixed
# After fixing the issues needed, we can remove the permission we added in step 1.

h5. Workaround for a specific issue in 4.5.x
# Add Browser projects permission to the Reporter role (accessing a URL like this: http://localhost:2990/jira/secure/admin/EditPermissions!default.jspa?schemeId=10000)
# Find an issue in a broken state (aka: with a Comment: for customer stop condition that should’ve been triggered but isn’t)
# Delete all the SLA information for it in the database with a SQL query like this:
{noformat}
delete
from customfieldvalue
where issue in (
    select id as issue_id
    from jiraissue
    where project = (
        select id as project_id
        from project
        where pkey = '{PROJECT_KEY}' -- project key
    )
      and issuenum = {ISSUE_NUMBER} -- issue number
)
  and customfield in (
    select id as sla_custom_field_id
    from customfield
    where customfieldtypekey = 'com.atlassian.servicedesk:sd-sla-field' --sla field type key
);{noformat}
# Run the following call to clear Jira’s cache (remember to change the authorisation strategy to something that makes sense for the instance):
{noformat}
curl --location \
     --request DELETE 'http://localhost:2990/jira/rest/internal/1.0/cache/app' \
     --header 'Authorization: Basic {BASE64_AUTH_STRING}'{noformat}
# Enable the sd.sla.fix.timeline feature-flag, if it's not already enabled
# Run the reconstruction for the affected issue via REST API, like so (remember to change the authorisation strategy to something that makes sense for the instance):
{noformat}
curl --location --request POST 'http://localhost:2990/jira/rest/servicedesk/1/servicedesk/sla/admin/task/destructive/reconstruct' \
     --header 'Authorization: Basic {BASE64_AUTH_STRING}' \
     --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
     --data-raw '["{ISSUE_KEY}"]'{noformat}
# SLA is now fixed
# After fixing the issues needed, we can remove the permission we added in step 1.

h5. Workaround for a specific issue in 4.9.0
# Add Browser projects permission to the Reporter role (accessing a URL like this: http://localhost:2990/jira/secure/admin/EditPermissions!default.jspa?schemeId=10000)
# Find an issue in a broken state
# Enable the sd.sla.fix.timeline feature-flag, if it's not already enabled
# Run the reconstruction with force via REST API, like so (remember to change the authorisation strategy to something that makes sense for the instance):
{noformat}curl --location --request POST 'http://localhost:2990/jira/rest/servicedesk/1/servicedesk/sla/admin/task/destructive/reconstruct/force' \
     --header 'Authorization: Basic {BASE64_AUTH_STRING}' \
     --header 'Content-Type: application/json' \
     --data-raw '["{ISSUE_KEY}"]'{noformat}
# SLA is now fixed
# After fixing the issues needed, we can remove the permission we added in step 1
fields.summary: SLAs with "Comment: for customers" condition wrongly recalculated and corrupted

fields.description:
I think [JSDSERVER-1743|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-1743], should be extended.

The limitations imposed on service desk customers should be relaxed to allow them to watch, comment and vote on any Jira issue. The issues can still be controlled using issue level security.

This is already available if you add customers as users but they don't need all the bells and whistles of user accounts. This suggestion would align our own customers with the way Atlassian treat their customers just like me creating this suggestion.

Our customers interacting and collaborating on our projects are much more likely to see your advertising when they're actively involved in project progression. Atlassian would effectively be placing their product and it's versatility into the hands of their customer's customers. This would be an impressive extension for Atlassian exposure and relatively easy to implement.
fields.summary: Allow service desk customers to watch, comment and vote on any Jira project

Juergen

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Due to a limitation, User Picker fields in Customer Portal is limited to only 10 users ([relevant Feature Request|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-6443]). This limitation becomes problematic when the 'Raise this request on behalf of' field doesn't restrict the search should there be multiple users matching the keyword. This still occurs even when searching the full name.
(i) The problem also occurs should the email address use the same string as the name

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create 10 users with similar name
** For example, create users named AAA Useryan, BBB Useryan, CCC Useryan and so on
# Now create another user called User Useryan
# Go to the Customer Portal where all the Users can access
# Raise a request and in the 'Raise this request on behalf of' field, try to search for User Useryan
# Notice how the results still show the other users as they still match the keyword

h3. Expected Results
The results would be filtered down to the users that strictly matches the keywords. Or prioritize the ones that better match the keyword by placing the users on top of the list.

h3. Actual Results
The results show all users that match any one of the keywords. If the desired user is beyond the 10th user, it would not be selectable due to the [list limitation|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-6443]
 !Useryan.png|thumbnail! 
 !Useryan2.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Either set the name or email to something that doesn't overlap with the multiple users
fields.summary: 'Raise this request on behalf of' field doesn't restrict/refine the list when there are multiple users matching the keyword

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The [SLA documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskserver/setting-up-slas-939926373.html] mentions SLA status is not recalculated for resolved issues:
{quote}The SLA status is only recalculated for open issues, not for resolved issues.
{quote}
However, SLA status for resolved issues is recalculated by changing the _Stop_ time on an SLA.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Service Desk project
 # Create an issue
 # Resolve the issue
 # Note SLA status and SLA timer has stopped for SLA _Time to resolution_, as an example.
 # Change the SLA *Stop* (_Finish counting time when)_ condition in the project settings from default _Resolution: Set_ to another value.
 ## Tested with: _Entered Status: Canceled_, _Comment: By Customer_, _Due Date changed_.
 # Return to the resolved issue and note the SLA status and SLA timer are active, even though the issue is resolved.

h3. Expected Results

No changes to an SLA will impact the SLA status for resolved issues.
h3. Actual Results

The SLA becomes ongoing again which can verified in SLA audit logs.
 * Issue resolved within 1h SLA:

!image-2020-05-11-09-34-17-113.png|width=578,height=190!
 * After changing *Stop* condition:

!image-2020-05-11-09-37-23-731.png|width=576,height=187!
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Changing the Stop time on an SLA recalculates SLA status for resolved issues

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
There may be cases as addressed in JSDSERVER-4732, customers may have installed Service Desk and then removed it. Over the years once they finally install this back, they realize that Service Desk would not work correctly due to upgrade tasks being missing. This can cause a huge overhead and friction as this would require downgrading the instance and upgrading back or modifying the database directly. 

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Instead of downgrading, which causes huge downtimes or updating the database which may be risky, it would be better if there is a script that the customer can install which contains all the upgrade tasks so that they may upgrade their databases easily and safely.
fields.summary: As a admin, I would like to be able to install a script to install all the upgrade tasks missed for Service Desk

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
This has been reported previously as a Bug and closed (JSDSERVER-747, JSDSERVER-2134). 

If this isn't considered a Bug it is definitely a product gap that needs to be considered.  Teams need to be able to move tickets around between JSD projects, especially if they are escalated to another team or if they were created in the wrong product initially. 

Suggestions:
 * When moving a ticket to another project the applicable SLA based upon the target project criteria should be applied and calculated.  An error should be noted if it can't be calculated based upon missing/different metadata between the projects used in the target SLA.
 * When moving a ticket that has an SLA in the target project, prompt for SLA application details.
 * Allow Project Admins the ability to apply SLAs for existing issues that don't have one applied due to this scenario.
 * Clearly state that you can't move tickets and that they should be cloned and linked issued.  This is obviously not ideal, since the customer doesn't care about ticket movement and only considers the point when they submit the ticket rather than when the clone is created.
fields.summary: Jira Service Desk SLAs don't work for items moved between projects

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:

At this time, Jira does not have any auditing capabilities when JSD Request Types and Forms are edited. Administrators would like to know when Request Types are created, edited, or deleted, or when the forms have fields edited as well.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Implement auditing capabilities on JSD features such as Request Types and Request Forms, containing information like when changes were made, who made the changes, and what the contents of the changes were.
fields.summary: Implement audit log for tracking changes to Request Types and Forms

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
customer comment remain internal if edited by an agent from the internal portal and then shared again to the customer.

The bug is reproducible in both JSD 4.6.1 and 4.8.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Jira Service Desk Server*. Using *Jira Service Desk Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDCLOUD-9076].
{panel}
 

h3. Problem Definition
Since Jira Service Desk CSAT (customer satisfaction) system currently permits users to re-submit their satisfaction star ratings multiple times (see also JSDSERVER-3839 ), Jira should be able to track these changes from a historical perspective.  Currently this is not possible.  Since the data is being stored on a custom field, as soon as the customer changes their star rating, that value overwrites the previous data for that interaction.
While the issue history in Jira does indicate the date/time of a satisfaction rating was provided, it does not track what that rating was.

In turn these original ratings are lost.

h3. Suggested Solution
Track the historical rating values in some manner.  Either in the issue history, or when viewing the changelog of the issue via the API, this information would be useful to be able to store and retrieve.


h3. Why this is important
It is possible for a customer to incorrectly update the wrong request, or worse update all their previous requests and change these values. This provides a very skewed CSAT values if done, and does not accurately reflect the original CSAT ratings given initial provided

h3. Workaround 
None
fields.summary: Service Desk Satisfaction ratings (CSAT) should be tracked historically

fields.description:
Usecase:

Jira Service desk used for many customers (a few hundred). Projects are based on products/services. Customers are separated into organisations. Any organisation can have several customer accounts on JSD. One (or more) of those customers is a representative of the organisation. The representative should see all of his organisation member requests, *but other members should not see his requests.* The representative should *get only the most important (if any) notifications* of other member requests (ex. create, resolve).

Also, the representative is defined in a *custom field.*

Possible technical implementation:

Add "representatives" field in organisations that can be set as a user/group/customField. "representatives" should be set per organisation and can be one or more. The "representative" could see other member requests (similar to "request participant") but other members may not see the "representatives" requests. Expand notification configurations to choose not only from "Reporter (Customer)" and "Customers involved" but also "representatives". This way the organisation "representatives" would get less notifications.
fields.summary: Expand JSD Organisation/notifications functionality

h3. Issue Summary

Internal comments on agents view trigger workbox notification in Confluence and are causing security problems in customer environments
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Have an application link setup configurated using OAuth with Confluence, in this case, v6.13.7
 # Create two users with application access and browse project permission only in a Jira Service Desk project
 # Create a new ticket
 # Add them as watchers in a ticket from the agent view
 # Add an internal comment from Jira service desk agent view
 # Check workbox notification in confluence by logging in as those users
 # Workbox notifications trigger in confluence from Jira only on 'Comments on issues that you are watching' our official documentation [Which notifications are included?|https://confluence.atlassian.com/doc/workbox-notifications-284365963.html#WorkboxNotifications-Whichnotificationsareincluded?] 

Detailed replication steps are in this screen recording: [^Replication_Steps_JiraServiceDesk.mp4]

The same behavior is not replicable in Jira Software when adding restricted comments: [^Not_replicable_JiraSoftware.mp4]
h3. Expected Results

Internal comments should not be triggered as workbox notification in Confluence, should be handled in the same way as done in Jira Software
h3. Actual Results

Internal comments are being triggered to customers as workbox notifications in Confluence, which are causing security problems in customer environments
h3. Workaround

Refer to the heading 'Stopping Jira applications from sending notifications to Confluence' in this KB article [Configuring Workbox Notifications|https://confluence.atlassian.com/conf613/configuring-workbox-notifications-964961270.html]

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Getting blank screen after refreshing customer portal where session timed out.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Open customer portal and navigate to a project
 # Wait until the session times out
 # Refresh the page

h3. Expected Results

User will get logged out and login screen opens properly.
h3. Actual Results

The login screen is not loaded, instead blank page is shown.

HAR file shows some requests received response 401:
 !image-2020-04-15-14-36-54-963.png|thumbnail!

Access logs confirm 401 for some POST requests:
{noformat}
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx 630x653x1 - [15/Apr/2020:10:30:50 +0000] "POST /jira854/rest/webResources/1.0/resources HTTP/1.1" 401 20953 24 "http://localhost:8080/jira854/servicedesk/customer/portal/1/user/login?destination=portal%2F1" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.163 Safari/537.36" "-"
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx 635x673x1 - [15/Apr/2020:10:35:05 +0000] "POST /jira854/rest/webResources/1.0/resources HTTP/1.1" 401 20953 24 "http://localhost:8080/jira854/servicedesk/customer/portal/1/user/login?destination=portal%2F1" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_14_6) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/80.0.3987.163 Safari/537.36" "-"
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx 640x730x1 - [15/Apr/2020:10:40:06 +0000] "POST /jira854/rest/webResources/1.0/resources HTTP/1.1" 401 20953 23 "http://localhost:8080/jira854/servicedesk/customer/portal/1/user/login?destination=portal%2F1" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.14; rv:72.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/72.0" "-"
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx 640x731x1 - [15/Apr/2020:10:40:07 +0000] "POST /jira854/rest/webResources/1.0/resources HTTP/1.1" 401 20953 21 "http://localhost:8080/jira854/servicedesk/customer/portal/1/user/login?destination=portal%2F1" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.14; rv:72.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/72.0" "-"
xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx 640x732x1 - [15/Apr/2020:10:40:07 +0000] "POST /jira854/rest/analytics/1.0/publish/bulk HTTP/1.1" 401 20953 24 "http://localhost:8080/jira854/servicedesk/customer/portal/1/user/login?destination=portal%2F1" "Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.14; rv:72.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/72.0" "-"
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

h4. Workaround 1 (long term)

# Extend session timeout according to make sure sessions don't time out for a longer period of time: [Change the default session timeout to avoid user logout in Jira server|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/change-the-default-session-timeout-to-avoid-user-logout-in-jira-server-604209887.html]
# On Service Desk login screen, select "Keep me logged in"

h4. Workaround 2 (short term)

# Open Jira's main URL "<JIRA_BASE_URL>/secure/Dashboard.jspa" in a separate tab.  Note that you don't have to log in from here, just opening this URL in a new tab will help
# Go back to the customer portal URL and refresh it. You'll see that the page will load.

h4. Workaround 3 (short term)

Clear the browser cookies.

h3. Note

* The issue is not always reproducible. In some cases, the login screen gets loaded successfully. We were not able to determine exact circumstances under which the issue is not reproducible.
* We managed to reproduce the issue using Firefox, Edge (Chromium engine), Chrome and Internet Explorer.
* Issue does not seem to be present in Jira 7.13.x.
fields.summary: Blank screen after refreshing customer portal where session timed out

fields.description:
There are two different ways to create/update issues by emails:
 - The first one is using Jira Mail handler. This is a global Jira Core feature where admins can configure Jira to receive and process emails. Jira can receive emails from licensed users to create issues or add comments and attachments to existing issues automatically. The process is explained in this KB on [Creating issues and comments from email|https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiraserver085/creating-issues-and-comments-from-email-981155478.html]. As you can see in the KB, there is a note mentioning the following, which takes us to the second option:
{quote}If you're looking for a help desk solution, it may be more practical to use Jira Service Desk, rather than setting up Jira Core or Jira Software for this purpose.

Jira Service Desk uses a built-in processor to receive and process issue requests from emails. Issues created in Jira Service Desk don't require the sender to have a license to create, view, comment, add attachments, or transition issues. 
{quote}
 - The second one is a Jira service desk property and you can [read more about receiving email requests with Jira Service Desk here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/servicedeskserver033/receiving-requests-by-email-861255251.html].

As of today, there are a few differences between these two methods. For instance, using Service Desk mail handler:
 * Customers that are included in creating tickets from emails do not need to have application access (license) or to comply with the project permission scheme (only the customer permission configuration is needed) to be allowed to open new requests or add comments.
 * You can use automation rules that are only suitable for this mail handler.

 On the other side, Jira Mail Handlers are much more configurable than the JSD Mail Handler:
 * For example,  you can decide if the mail handler will only create new issues, only add new comments, or do both (while the JSD Mail Handler does either by default).
 * You can configure a default reporter, a catch email address, some regex expressions to decide how the quotes email will be stripped, etc… (which is not possible with the JSD Mail Handler).

I understand that this is related to the fact that JSD was added as a plugin to Jira and therefore had its own mail framework. This suggestion is to come up with a consolidation by taking the best of both mail functionalities which will reduce the confusion and offer a better configurability for JSD mail functionality.
fields.summary: Consolidate Jira Service Desk Mail functionality with Jira Core Mail Handler

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When attaching an image using within the email body, the comment shows an incorrect image and end up with two different images.

Example:
Drag and Drop OR copy-paste a picture in the email body image001.png then check out the text mode in the comment, it points to the correct image which is image001.png.

However, when sending another image with the same name image001.png using Drag and Drop OR copy-paste a picture in the email body, the image uploads correctly with the new name image001-1.png. 

But the comment does not get updated and remains with the original name of the image which is image001.png which is incorrect behaviour, and within the same comment, it will include the new name of the picture which is image001-1.png. So *you will end up with two different pictures within the same comment*. One is correct and the other one isn't.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Attach a picture in the email body using Drag and Drop OR copy-paste (Example image001.png)
 # Send the email 
 # Check the comment in "Text" Mode, it should be 
{code:java}
!image001.png|thumbnail!
{code}
 # Now create a new email and attach *another picture* in the email body using Drag and Drop OR copy-paste with the same name (image001.png).
 # The image is uploaded with the name (image001-1.png), which is the correct behaviour as this was fixed in Jira 8.6 and above (https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-2169)
 # Check out the comment in "Text" Mode, it shows *two pictures* 
 #* The *first* picture attached with the name (image001.png) 
 #** {code:java}
!image001.png|thumbnail!
{code} *which is incorrect.*
#* The *second* picture attached with the name (image001-1.png)
#** {code:java}
!image001-1.png|thumbnail!
{code}


h3. Expected Results
When checking out the comment in text mode after uploading the second image, the comment should contain *only* {code:java} !image001-1.png|thumbnail! {code} to show the correct picture attached.

h3. Actual Results
When checking out the comment in text mode after uploading the second image, the comment shows {code:java} !image001.png|thumbnail! {code} which is incorrect because it shows the first picture attached, it also shows *the second picture* {code:java} !image001-1.png|thumbnail! {code} 

*Text Mode*
*  !text mode.png|thumbnail! 
*Visual Mode*
*  !Vmode.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

Currently, the workaround for this issue is to use the "Attach tool" in the emails to add the image to the email as an attachment (not in the email body).

*  !Attach tool.png|thumbnail! 

OR 

You could also upload images using a different name (e.g image001.png) & (image002.png).
fields.summary: When attaching an image using within the email body, the comment shows an incorrect image and end up with two different images

Thread dumps indicated the common activity was related to getting permissions from Crowd:  
{code:java}
--- com.atlassian.jira.security.DefaultGlobalPermissionManager.hasPermission
--- com.atlassian.jira.security.DefaultGlobalPermissionManager.loadPermissions
--- com.atlassian.jira.security.groups.RequestCachingGroupManager.getGroupNamesForUser(RequestCachingGroupManager.java:193)
--- com.atlassian.jira.cache.request.RequestCacheImpl.get(RequestCacheImpl.java:42)
--- com.atlassian.jira.security.groups.RequestCachingGroupManager$$Lambda$175/791274807.load(Unknown Source)
--- com.atlassian.jira.cache.request.RequestCacheImpl.get(RequestCacheImpl.java:42)
--- com.atlassian.jira.security.groups.RequestCachingGroupManager.lambda$new$0(RequestCachingGroupManager.java:43)
--- com.atlassian.jira.security.groups.DefaultGroupManager.getGroupsForUser(DefaultGroupManager.java:393)
--- com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdServiceImpl.search(CrowdServiceImpl.java:157)
--- com.atlassian.crowd.embedded.core.CrowdServiceImpl.searchNestedGroupRelationships(CrowdServiceImpl.java:216)
--- com.atlassian.crowd.manager.application.ApplicationServiceGeneric.searchNestedGroupRelationships(ApplicationServiceGeneric.java:1751)
{code}
h3. Workaround
 # Type faster. ;) 
 # Block workload search API endpoint.
 # Decrease search complexity by reducing number of users, SLAs, nested crowd groups, etc.
 # Upgrade from JSD 3.x to JSD ER 4.5+ for approximately 25% better workload search performance.
 # Use another JSD instance to handle only workload search requests.
fields.summary: Slowly typing query into JSD Project Workload search causes service unavailability

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
In case that a request is shared with the organization and a customer that has access to the ticket would like to add self as a participant, JIRA Service Desk would not let them.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an Organization in a Service Desk project e.g. OrgA
# Create two customer e.g Customer1 and Customer2
# Add the two customers to OrgA
# Login to the Project Portal as Customer1
# Raised a request and shared it to the Organization
# Logout and login back as Customer 2
# Access the same request and add self, using the "Share" button.

h3. Expected Results
- Customer2 will be listed as the participants

h3. Actual Results
- The error "Sorry, but the following users do not belong to your organizations" will be shown.
 !image-2020-04-03-18-45-21-114.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Can't add self through the "Share" button

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
Currently, when a user in multiple organizations, they can share an issue to an organization that users on the ticket are not members of. This could cause sharing with users or organizations that should not have access to a ticket of that type. We would like an option to restrict sharing based on the organizations the users on the ticket are not a member of. 

Example:
-Purple: Org 1, Org 2
-Blue: Org 1
-Red: Org 2

Blue is creating a ticket and wants to share with Purple for an issue with Org 1 issue. Purple can access as they are a member of Org 1 and Org 2. Purple can then share the ticket with Red for the same reason. Red should not have access to the ticket based on their role within the company/team.
fields.summary: Add Option to Restrict Sharing of Issues To Organizations of the Reporter or Assignee

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

 If the *Browse Projects* permission was granted to *Any logged in user* , the *Public email comments* setting from *Applications > Email Requests* does not work as expected: if a user who is not involved in a JSD ticket sends an email including the issue key of this ticket, the JSD Mail Handler creates a new ticket instead of adding a new comment. Note that if this permission is removed, then a new comment is added to the ticket.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure a service desk project with the global/project settings as per the attached screenshots, basically allowing public comments
 # Grant 'Browse Project' permission to 'Any logged in user'
 # We have two users, say user1 and user2
 # user1 has created a ticket in the portal and is the reporter
 # user2 has no access to the project and no Jira application access as well
 # user1 would have received an email after creating a ticket
 # user1 forwards this mail to user2
 # user2 who is not involved in the request (by not being the reporter nor a participant) replies all to the email, to try to add a comment to the request
 # Jira service desk should check if the Issue key-number combination and add the public comment, but it creates a new ticket” into the “Expected Results” section, since it describes well what is the expected behavior

h3. Expected Results

Public comment should be added
h3. Actual Results

New tickets are getting created, even with the issue key in the subject
h3. Workaround

Remove 'Browse Project' permission to 'Any logged in user' in the JSD project
fields.summary: Public comments not added as a comment but creates a new ticket if the Browse Project permission is granted to Any logged in user

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Whenever you try to add a field to a screen, the custom field type is displayed on the right side of the screen. However, a very light shade of gray is used, which could be difficult to read for users with reduced visibility.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Click on the *Jira Administration Icon* > *Issues*.
# Select *Screens* at the sidebar.
# Click on *Configure* for any of the screens.
# Scroll down to the bottom of the page and locate the *Field name* drop-down menu. 
# Click on the *Drop-down* arrow and see the custom field types that will appear to the right side of the screen.

 !Screen Shot 2020-03-27 at 23.41.10.png|thumbnail! 


h3. Expected Results

The custom field types will be easily readable.

h3. Actual Results

The light shade of gray used makes the custom field types difficult to read.

h3. Workaround

There is no known workaround for this behavior.

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
We have Jira Service Desk Data Center with SSO 2.0 enabled and working very well.  We would like to create separate global admin accounts from those users normal accounts.  With SSO 2.0 set as Primary Authentication, there is no method to login as a different user.  

There are other needs for this ability also:
 * accessing an individual node for a loadbalanced cluster becomes nearly impossible.  Currently I use curl and a rest command to reindex when that is necessary.  
 * Doing any configuration of the AD user directory as a Jira local user would require setting SSO to secondary, then logging in, making any changes, then set SSO back to primary.  This would be a jarring experience for end users.
fields.summary: Allow for different login with SSO as primary.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

customer portal search bar results are inconsistent when the request type name contains *dash* character within spaces and a *slash* / character
 This behaviour seems to happen when the request types name contains a the *dash - character within the spaces* (ex. Jira/Confluence - Problem) and a *slash /* character . Not when there is no space between a word and another (ex. Jira/Confluence-Problem).
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 * define some request types a Jira Service Desk portal which contains a the dash - character within the spaces and a *slash /* character (ex. Jira/Confluence - Problem):
 !Screenshot_2020-03-27_at_09_56_52.jpg|thumbnail!
 * in the portal search bar try to search for one of the word contained in the request types. The results are then retrieved:
 !Screenshot 2020-03-27 at 09.58.38.png|thumbnail!
 * try then to search 2 words contained into the request type (ex. confluence problem):
 !Screenshot 2020-03-27 at 09.59.15.png|thumbnail!
 * observe that the results are not retrieved at all only when the request type contains the dash within spaces.
 * try instead to search 2 words contained into the request type for a request type which contain the dash but not within spaces:
 !Screenshot 2020-03-27 at 09.57.51.png|thumbnail! 
 From the screenshot above also observe that when there is not also the slash / in combination with the dash, also the request type confluence - problem is retrieved.

h3. Expected Results

the search should return all the request types which contains a combination of the searched words
h3. Actual Results

the search results are inconsistent when the request type name contains a dash within the spaces and a slash /.
h3. Workaround

Currently the only workaround is to avoid to put the dash - within spaces
fields.summary: customer portal search bar results are inconsistent when the request type name contains dash character within spaces and a slash / character

project.name: Jira Service Management Server and Data Center

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
JSD's Automation webhooks behave differently to Jira webhooks when using Jira behind outbound http-proxy.  Jira webhooks respect the NonProxyHosts configuration while Service Desk webhooks always go through the proxy. This can also lead to a scenario where using JSDs automation to fire webhooks, they look like they are sent, but they timeout and/or fail silently.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# In the setenv.sh/.bat we set additional JVM arguments (JVM_SUPPORT_RECOMMENDED_ARGS) with:
#* http.proxyHost
#* http.proxyPort
#* http.proxyUser
#* http.proxyPassword
#* https.proxyHost
#* https.proxyPort
#* https.proxyUser
#* https.proxyPassword
#* https.nonProxyHosts
# Add a JSD automation that triggers a webhook.
# Perform an action that triggers this automation rule.

h3. Expected Results
The web request is sent through the proxy configured in the JVM arguments and reaches its destination.

h3. Actual Results
The webhook is triggered, but it does not follow the proxy configuration and does not go out of Jira, failing silently.

h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Webhooks from Service Desk automation do not follow proxy logic

fields.description:
As per the fix provided on [JSDSERVER-6769|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JSDSERVER-6769], now the lines will be broken by whole words but not by single characters. However, this is still not useful for the date fields, especially where we have long date formats(dd MMMM YYYY). The date fields still get split into two lines:
!screenshot_224.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround
Currently, there are two possible workarounds to fix this behavior:
*Workaround 1:* Adding the below darkfeature flag to Jira disables the react UI enhancements and the issue is not reproducible any more:
{code}sd.queue.react.table.disabled{code}
(i) Though using the dark feature does restore the rendering, but that will essentially disable the whole agent experience improvements and UI enhancements like the ability to do sorting on columns and scrolling enhancements.

*Workaround 2:* This behavior is mainly caused due to fixed column width 70 px for date fields which is not enough for some date format on some OS/Browser combinations. You can modify the project-queue-react-table.11ec2bcb91b8f432dc30.css in the servicedesk-frontend-plugin-4.7.1-REL-0008.jar and changed the width from 70px to 75px or 80px.
fields.summary: Increase the width of the date columns on the queue to prevent long date time formats from splitting into next line
